baseline_groups.claim_summary: Children of Mexican immigrant parents who arrived in the US at ages 0-8 are more likely to not identify as Hispanic than children of parents who arrived at ages 9-17.
baseline_groups.notes: Three baseline specs represent a control-progression from no controls to full controls. The papers preferred specification is baseline (full controls), which yields an insignificant coefficient (p=0.10). The no-controls and basic-controls baselines are significant but largely driven by confounding through intermarriage.

global_notes: The paper tests whether parents age at arrival affects childs Hispanic identification. The core claim is sensitive to controls: significant without intermarriage controls but insignificant with full controls. 62 total specs. Heterogeneity interaction specs change the treatment variable to an interaction term and are non-core. The placebo uses a different outcome. Logit/probit are core_method but different scale. Alternative treatment cutoffs test the same concept.
